fields.description: During the [Mail Server|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Running+the+Setup+Wizard#RunningtheSetupWizard-Step7.MailServer] step of the installation wizard, if emails with Uppercased chars are used, message *The supplied email address is invalid.* is displayed.
fields.summary: During the installation wizard, emails with Uppercased Chars are not accepted

fields.description:
I have configured a custom directory connector (via the RemoteDirectory interface). An exception in this connector prevented me from logging on to the Crowd instance at all.

The exception in the custom directory connector should prevent users within this directory from logging on etc, but it should not prevent the admin user, stored in the internal directory, from logging on.

fields.description:
Symptoms as reported by one of the users experiencing this bug:
{quote}
New users, who have never used Confluence or JIRA before, cannot log in with their Windows account and password. They get a message saying 'Sorry, your username and password are incorrect. Please try again'. When we test the users credentials in the Application 'Authentication Test' we get a 'Successful verification', but the user cannot log in to Confluence or JIRA.

I have found that if I update the Delegated Authentication Directory BASE DN to an invalid value and then reset the same BASE DN to the correct value the users can log in. This seems to only be valid for a short period of time. Eventually any new users attempting to log in are not allowed, getting the same 'Sorry, your username and password are incorrect. Please try again' message.
{quote}

Nothing helpful in the logs.

Affecting both JIRA and Confluence.

Current workaround is to manually add users to the delegated authentication directory.
fields.summary: User authentication fails for new users when using delegated authentication directory with auto-add-to-directory enabled

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd demands a Base DN (unique and not empty) to be able to connect to a LDAP Server. 

Would be useful to allow a connector to see all the content of the LDAP Server if the Base DN is empty. In the same way, would be useful to allow multiple Base DNs to simplify the connection to many Domains in a same server. This would also help cases when Objects from one Domain make references to objects in a different Domain (ie. A user in one domain is a member of a group located in a different domain). In the same way Crowd merges the group memberships to allow Apps to see a single group, Directories could merge all the Domains specified in a connector. 

To be implemented in Embedded Crowd as https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/EMBCWD-881
fields.summary: Support empty Base DN definitions for Generic Directory Connector

fields.description:
Taken verbatim from http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257346810&#257346810

Hey All,

Ive created a patch against Crowd-Apache-Connector (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache)

To allow Idle session timeouts in basic http auth.

It does this by maintaining a Cache::FileCache table (the same as Crowds auth cache).

The session is based on the remote ip (fetched from the apache request object) and the supplied username.
It performs the session check AFTER they have been successfully authenticated..this is to stop storing sessions on random user connects.

Configuration is pretty simple and by default idle session timeouts are disabled.

Id like for Atlassian to include this patch in further versions of the crowd apache connector as this allows basic http auth with crowd in apache to be compliant for things like PCI DSS which requires idle sessions be logged out.

Documentation:
New configuration options are added to support this:
PerlSetVar CrowdIdleSessionsEnabled off
PerlSetVar CrowdIdleSessionsTimeout 300
PerlSetVar CrowdIdleSessionsLocation /tmp/CrowdIdleSessionsCache

I should also note, currently sessions do not expire...this is because technically someone could leave an authenticated browser open for an indefinite time and if the session has been cleaned up then they can refresh and still be authenticated...

UPDATE: Noticed a bug in checking if CrowdIdleSessionsEnabled was set to off it wasnt taking effect. have uploaded v2 which fixes this
Any Questions/Criticisms please let me know.

Cheers
Brendan
fields.summary: Patch for Crowd authentication within apache for idle session timeouts

fields.description:
Request for enhancement to support automatic database upgrades with Oracle.

Currently automatic database upgrades are only supported with MySQL and Postgres (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Upgrading+Crowd) but Oracle is a supported database (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Supported+Platforms) that should also support automatic upgrades.

In our deployment we have a very large directory and high uptime requirements. XML backup and restore for each patch upgrade of Crowd is not practical.

Possibly only supporting automatic upgrade from recent versions or between patch releases rather than major version upgrades would be enough for us.
fields.summary: support automatic database upgrade with Oracle

fields.description:
Currently Crowd offers in-memory LDAP caching for:
- Active Directory
- Apache DS 1.5.x

It would be very useful to be able to cache LDAP data, for all LDAP directories. Also, rather than caching in-memory, it would be beneficial to cache the data in the database so that:
- all queries hit the database (only authentication, synchronisation and mutation calls go to LDAP)
- all data is available when Crowd starts up (as opposed to lazy caching)

The user should be able to synchronise the cache with LDAP by manually clicking a button to synchronise and should also be able to set a polling interval for automatic periodic synchronisation.
fields.summary: Database-Backed LDAP Caching

fields.description:
{{com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric#storeUserAttributes}} has a guard around the store logic where it checks for UPDATE_USER permissions.

When used in Confluence this means we can't store user properties for users that are stored in a read only directory.

As discussed, we need to consider the following:
# Confluence adding the UPDATE_USER permission when creating directories, even READ_ONLY ones.  This could complicate the confluence UI as it may look like the user has permission to EDIT a user (other non-property fields) when they don't.
# As above but introduce a new permission UPDATE_USER_PROPERTIES which is on when confluence embeds crowd.  This will be a hidden permission which will be turned on and off by crowd as UPDATE_USER is mutated.
# Remove the check entirely which changes the meaning of this permission and might have detrimental effect on plugins or external applications.
fields.summary: Remove UPDATE_USER permission check when setting UserProperties

fields.description:
*Details of the vulnerability:*

We have identified and fixed a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the Crowd login form. XSS vulnerabilities potentially allow an attacker to embed their own Javascript or code into a Crowd page. An attacker's text and script might be displayed to other people viewing the Crowd page. This is potentially damaging to your company's reputation.

This issue is reported in our security advisory on this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/AawCDQ

You can read more about XSS attacks at cgisecurity, CERT and other places on the web:
* http://www.cgisecurity.com/xss-faq.html
* http://www.cert.org/advisories/CA-2000-02.html

*Mitigation:*

If you cannot upgrade to Crowd 2.0.5 immediately, you can fix this XSS vulnerability by disallowing request parameters in generated URLs. You can globally turn off the inclusion of request parameters in generated URLs by editing your WebWork properties file:

# Edit the {{webwork.properties}} file located at {{\{CROWD-INSTALLATION-DIRECTORY\}\crowd-webapp\WEB-INF\classes\webwork.properties}}.
# Add the following property as a new line in the file:
{code}
webwork.url.includeParams=none
{code}
# Save the file.
# Restart Crowd.

The WebWork documentation has more about the [webwork.properties|http://www.opensymphony.com/webwork/wikidocs/webwork.properties.html] file.
fields.summary: Crowd login form may be vulnerable to XSS attacks

fields.description:
Currently Crowd allows admins to set a single sub-domain level only for the Cookie pattern.

Example:
*URL Domain:* abc.xyz.example.com
*SSO Domain Allowed:* .xyz.example.com
*SSO Domain Not Allowed:* .example.com (it would reach two sub-domain levels)

If the browsers don't respect rfc2965, there is an opportunity to allow the definition of *.example.com* as the cookie pattern and support many subdomains for SSO.

Currently the code defined at class *SSOUtils* blocks this behavior.

* This problem is affecting Crowd 2.4.0
fields.summary: Make Crowd's cookie domain validation consistent with RFC 6265

fields.description:
According to the documentation, the active flag on a directory should behave this way:

- users in inactive directories will not be able to access mapped applications

But at the moment, the flag is completely ignored by Crowd. Rather than fixing it to behave as above, for Embedded Crowd we need the directory active flag to behave this way:

- inactive directories are not included when searching for users, groups or memberships
- inactive directories are still displayed in the UI
- inactive directories can be removed from application mappings.

The following documentation will need to be updated when the behaviour changes:

- http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+an+Internal+Directory
- http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+an+LDAP+Directory+Connector
- http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+a+Custom+Directory+Connector
- http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+a+Delegated+Authentication+Directory
fields.summary: Active flag on directory is not respected

fields.description:
After our 2.0 release, the *javax.naming.ServiceUnavailableException* has become more common.

As a workaround we've been suggesting the following configuration in the Crowd JAVA_OPTS (apache-tomcat/bin/setenv.sh).
{code}
-Dcom.sun.jndi.ldap.connect.pool.timeout=3
{code}

The fact that it has been working, points that the problem may be in the connection pool (or connections individually).

Another workaround that solved the problem was to start 'TCPMon' on AD-Server and listens on port 390 and pass the data to port 389 (use x.x.x.x:390 as URL in the Crowd-Directory Setup).

Unfortunately, I couldn't reproduce the problem locally.

fields.description:
Currently, Crowd has more than one cache for each data type (ie Users, Groups and Memberships) and different methods that benefit from the same information, store data in different caches.

From the *CachingGroupMembershipManager*, examples for memberships:
|| Methods || Cache || Server API ||
| basicCache.isMemberInGroupCache
basicCache.getMembers | ALL_GROUP_MEMBERS_CACHE | isGroupMember
findGroupByName |
| basicCache.isMember | GROUP_MEMBERSHIP_CACHE | isGroupMember |
| basicCache.getAllMemberships | ALL_USER_MEMBERSHIPS_CACHE | findGroupMemberships |

Before calling Server APIs again, all the caches should be checked for the needed information. This applies for Users and Groups as well.

fields.description:
The {{findGroupByName}} on the {{SpringLDAPConnector}} calls {{findGroupWithAttributesByName}} as the calls are inherently identical as LDAP directories don't have custom attributes.

However, when a group is found, it's memberships (memberDNs) are brought back. This is can be slow for really large groups. For example, using OpenLDAP, a group with 40k members takes 5 seconds to retrieve. The {{findGroupByName}} method is called from many places, including {{addUserToGroup}}, etc, to check for the group's existence.

Fixing this doesn't seem trivial as the culling of attributes is done on the client layer - ie. we get all the attributes for the group object back on from the LDAP server and map only the attributes we want on the client layer. Since the actual transport is what's looking to be costly, we'll need to modify the search to only request particular attributes.

Further, we will need to investigate where we actually need the memberDNs (eg. group membership search) and when we only want the group name / active flag.
fields.summary: Finding an LDAP group is slow when the group has many members

fields.description:
Andrew Reid is improving the Crowd Apache and Subversion connectors and the related documentation. The purpose of this JIRA issue is to manage the documentation updates.

======================
BACKGROUND INFO
======================

This is a summary of the work Andrew is doing, including the packaging and documentation changes (and assorted bug fixes) for the Crowd/Apache connector:

1. Provide the Crowd Apache Connector in the following formats:
    RPM package(s) for Red Hat Linux versions 4 and 5.
    DEB package(s) for Debian Linux version 5 and Ubuntu 9.10
    PKG package(s) for Solaris 10 and OpenSolaris 2009.06
    PPM package(s) for ActivePerl for Windows version 5.8 and 5.10

    (It may be the case that only one install package is needed for similar operating systems or different version of the same operating system).

2. Write detailed step-by-step instructions (in the Crowd Confluence docs) for going from a default OS install to a working  Apache/Subversion/Crowd integration (not including instructions for installing Crowd itself) for each supported OS.

3. Fix the following JIRA issues:
* CWD-1637: CrowdAuth doesn't expire cached app tokens if CrowdAuth timeout longer than Crowd timeout.
* CWD-1814: Crowd Apache Connector doesn't escape svn path names when using them in regexps.
* CWD-895: Apache connector with CrowdAuthzSVNAccessFile fails with group names containing spaces.

======================
DOCUMENTATION UPDATES
======================

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Update the Apache page, moving the installation instructions to a separate page per OS and keep the config section on the main page.
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache
Draft is at:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Copy+of+Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache

* {color:green}DONE:{color} New page for Red Hat Linux
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache+on+Red+Hat+Linux

* {color:green}DONE:{color} New page for Debian and Ubuntu
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache+on+Debian+or+Ubuntu+Linux

* {color:green}DONE:{color} New page for Solaris
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache+on+Solaris

* {color:green}DONE:{color} New page for OpenSolaris
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache+on+OpenSolaris

* {color:green}DONE:{color} New page for for Windows
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Apache+on+Windows

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Tech writer review of the new and updated pages.
_Fri 9 July: Review complete. Some questions emailed to Andrew Reid._
_Mon 12 July: Answer received and docs updated._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Update the Subversion page.
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Subversion
_Only minor clarifications applied. No need for major update, nor for a separate page per OS, because it's all about config not installation._


* {color:green}DONE:{color} Find out whether they need to add the applications (Apache and Subversion) to Crowd in the usual way too. Also groups.
_Fri 9 July: Question emailed to Andrew Reid._
_Mon 12 July: Answer received and docs updated._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Discuss where we'll host the connectors. I'd suggest PAC.
_Fri 9/7: Andrew R to set up PAC and SPAC._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Discuss with Justin and DoF: Crowd Apache updated connectors part of Crowd 2.0.5 or just publish/release when ready? Tests and maint?
_Answer: They're separate from any Crowd release. We can publish when ready._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Dev and PM review of the new and updated pages.

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Add the PAC URLs to each of the above pages, when available.

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Check the Solaris / Subersion integration once the problem is solved.
_Mon 12 July: Subversion integration is proving difficult on Solaris because Sun/Oracle don't provide a Subversion package that works with the version of Apache that ships with Solaris. Neither does anyone else. Working on an installation that replaces the standard Solaris apache with one from the Sunfreeware project (http://www.sunfreeware.com/programlistintel10.html#subversion4)._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Support review of the new pages
_Thurs 15 July: Requested by email._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Publish pages.
_Tues 20 July: All published._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Clean up comments on existing pages.
_Tues 20 July: All removed._

* {color:green}DONE:{color} Make sure the following JIRA issues are marked as fixed:
* CWD-1637: CrowdAuth doesn't expire cached app tokens if CrowdAuth timeout longer than Crowd timeout.
* CWD-1814: Crowd Apache Connector doesn't escape svn path names when using them in regexps.
* CWD-895: Apache connector with CrowdAuthzSVNAccessFile fails with group names containing spaces.

fields.description:
"Reset password" calls
* com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.resetPassword(), which calls
* com.atlassian.crowd.integration.authentication.PasswordHelper.generateRandomPassword(), which calls
* org.apache.commons.lang.RandomStringUtils.randomAlphanumeric(8) ([link|http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/tags/LANG_2_4/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/RandomStringUtils.java?revision=638713&view=markup]), which eventually calls
* java.util.Random.nextInt(int) ([link|http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Random.html]), which
* _uses a 48-bit seed, which is modified using a linear congruential formula. (See Donald Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, Volume 2, Section 3.2.1.)_

Several obvious flaws:
* What's Random() seeded with? It's often something predictable by an attacker.
* java.util.Random() makes no attempt at being secure — knowing a given 48-bit state trivially gives you every previous and future state. The password has 47.6 log{~}2{~}(62{^}8{^}) = 47.6 bits of entropy, so I just reset my password twice, crack the state, reset my password, and reset someone else's password.

It's not that difficult to do a distributed brute-force of a 48-bit state, especially when the implementation gives you the 6.5 bits for free. There's also plenty of cryptanalysis, some of which might be relevant.
fields.summary: Automatically generated passwords (e.g. password reset) use insecure java.util.Random

fields.description:
For various reasons, I have Crowd set up to do anonymous bind. That's fine, until Firefox does an autofill (Firefox's auto-fill seems to have become more aggressive since the field-rename in CWD-599). I can remove the ldap.userdn but not the ldap.password — a blank password apparently means "don't modify". To fix this, I have to poke the database (good thing I'm not using HSQLDB).

Moreover, in addition to losing the password (CWD-1763), the "test connection" button also uses the password in the field instead of the one in the database. This means the "Test Connection" button will fail where it would otherwise succeed.

A simple (if slightly horrible) solution would be to treat {{\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*}} as a string meaning "whatever is in the database". This means it's impossible to set the password to eight asterisks, but that's something we can live with. It also means the "test connection" button can know when it has to pull the password out of the database.

Not quite sure which component this goes in; it's largely a UI problem.
fields.summary: Cannot un-set ldap.password to return to anonymous bind

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 20 October 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We’re happy to inform you that we’ve released [Crowd 4.2|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-4-2-release-notes-1019381976.html] which encrypts all passwords to external systems that are stored in the Crowd’s database. These are:
* Passwords that allows Crowd to connect to LDAP / AD directory
* Remote Crowd directory application passwords
* Azure AD web application keys
* SMTP mail passwords
* Proxy passwords

We’d like to emphasize that the encryption of *application.password* stored in *crowd.properties* file which is used by clients connecting to Crowd is not in the scope of this ticket. This suggestion is tracked in another ticket: [CWD-5649|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-5649].

Best regards,

Crowd team
{panel}
Anywhere that a password is stored in plaintext in Crowd's database, it should be encrypted. This will not stop a knowledgeable attacker, but may slow them down.
fields.summary: Encrypt all external system passwords in Crowd's database

fields.description:
Although the crowd.home setting in crowd-init.properties has been made, Crowd will attempt to create the plugins-temp and atlassian-crowd.log in the Current Working Directory (CWD). This has 3 possible effects:

1) at reboot, (on opensuse at least) tomcat happens to have /var/log/tomcat6 as CWD
2) when starting manually, if you happen to be in a tomcat owned directory, the files are created there
3) If in a non-tomcat owned directory, tomcat starts, but crowd gets all errory.

Crowd should use the crowd.home setting for this, and preferably create a log directory just like Confluence.
fields.summary: crowd creates log file and "plugins-temp" in Current Working Directory

fields.summary: Crowd trunk fails to startup with InvalidAuthenticationException

fields.description:
OSUser's LDAP integration (ie. JIRA's current LDAP integration) offers delegated authentication to LDAP and does not automatically create the user in locally on successful auth.

The current Crowd Delegated Authentication Directory _does_ perform the auto create on successful auth.

We could provide a flag to option to disable auto creation of users upon successful auth - this makes migration from JIRA's user management system easier as JIRA's LDAP config does not store the necessary data (such as user attribute mapping, eg. firstname, lastname, email, etc) to generate the user object for auto-creation.

If auto-create is disabled, then authentication should fail immediately if the user with the supplied username does not exist locally.
fields.summary: Provide option to disallow auto creation of users in the Delegated Authentication Directory (mimic OSUser LDAP behaviour)
